--- In junit@y..., "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@d...> wrote:
> > Should I test the one big public function 
> >(that actually inside merely calls several small functions)? 
> >
> >Let me make up an example:
> >
> >public void buildReport(ReportSpec spec, OutputStream out) {
> >  init(spec);
> >  ResultSet rec = reader.execute(spec);
> >  composeData(rec, spec, out);
> >  reader.close();
> >}
> >
> >look at this snippet as at an logical example. I wrote an own test 
> >for  each of internal functions by using MockObjects (if needed) 
but 
> >should I test buildReport function? It seems to me I'm just not 
able 
> >to.
> 
> Certainly, test it. One question: where does 'reader' come from? Is 
it
> a parameter to the constructor? If so, then you can easily mock all
> those objects.

That's the core of my question. A reader is being initialized from 
inside the function. I think that whichever decoupling of 
component/classes/functions I do still at a some point one of 
functions has to call the decoupled parts. In the production code I 
can't use mocks that deduces that there are functions which can't be 
tested (at least on UnitTest level). 
In my example buildReport knows how to create and init the reader and 
it only has connecting logic (how, when and which functions to call). 
I've tested each of them already.
> 
> A question for you: how would you test it?
I'm afraid I didn't get the answer. I test with help of mocks other 
functions accepting other my clsses as parameters. 

RR
